selected_quotes: The best diet ultimately is the one you can stick to long enough to achieve the weight loss goals that you desire. ht…
There is no optimal macronutrient distribution for wt mgmt, no one size fits all strategy that will suit everyone
Differences between diets r marginal.Weight loss improves metabolic markers, regardless of macronutrient composition ht…
Is There an Optimal Diet for Weight Loss Metabolic Health? Optimizing adherence is the most…
Lo-#fat diets improve LDL-#cholesterol most, lo-carb #diets triglycerides HDL, but none is best for #WeightLoss

citation.abstract: Individuals can lose body weight and improve health status on a wide range of energy (calorie) restricted dietary interventions. In this paper, we have reviewed the effectiveness of the most commonly utilized diets, including low-fat, low-carbohydrate and Mediterranean approaches in addition to commercial slimming programmes, meal replacements and newly-popularized intermittent fasting diets. We also consider the role of artificial sweeteners in weight management. Low-fat diets tend to improve LDL-cholesterol most, whilst lower-carbohydrate diets may preferentially improve triglycerides and HDL-cholesterol, however differences between diets are marginal. Weight loss improves almost all obesity related co-morbidities and metabolic markers, regardless of the macronutrient composition of the diet, but individuals do vary in preferences and ability to adhere to different diets. Optimizing adherence is the most important factor for weight loss success, and this is enhanced by regular professional contact and supportive behavioral change programs. Maintaining weight losses in the long-term remains the biggest challenge, and is undermined by an 'obesogenic' environment and biological adaptations that accompany weight loss.
citation.title: "Is there an optimal diet for weight management and metabolic health?”
